page.title: 13A DAY IN A FARMER'S LIFE
page.content: MORNING As I am seventy years old now, my day is nowhere near as busy as it used to be when I was younger, but it still begins at 6 a.m. when I get up, let my two dogs out and make a cup of tea for myself and my wife. I also give the dogs some milk. I then have a bath before breakfasting at 7.30 a.m. with my assistant who arrives to discuss the farm and plan the day's work. He then goes out to meet the other men who help to run the farm. At 8 o'clock work begins. The stablehand tacks up the horses and I ride round the farm, the local tracks and the land for about one and a half hours. When I get back we have a cup of coffee and then I help with the young horses we are breaking in. Sometimes I go to market if we are buying or selling cattle. I have a cold lunch at about noon.
